content.text: AJAX - Send a Request To a Server
The XMLHttpRequest object is used to exchange data with a server.
content.html: The XMLHttpRequest object is used to exchange data with a server.

content.text: Send a Request To a Server
To send a request to a server, we use the open() and send() methods of the XMLHttpRequest object:
content.html: To send a request to a server, we use the open() and send() methods of the XMLHttpRequest object:

content.code_html:
xhttp.open("GET", "ajax_info.txt", true);
xhttp.send();

Method Description
open(method, url, async) Specifies the type of request

method: the type of request: GET or POST
url: the server (file) location
async: true (asynchronous) or false (synchronous)
send() Sends the request to the server (used for GET)
send(string) Sends the request to the server (used for POST)

content.text: GET or POST?
GET is simpler and faster than POST, and can be used in most cases.
content.html: GET is simpler and faster than POST, and can be used in most cases.

content.text: However, always use POST requests when:
content.html: However, always use POST requests when:

content.text: GET Requests
A simple GET request:
content.html: A simple GET request:

content.code_html:
xhttp.open("GET", "demo_get.asp", true);
xhttp.send();

content.text: In the example above, you may get a cached result. To avoid this, add a unique ID to the URL:
content.html: In the example above, you may get a cached result. To avoid this, add a unique ID to the URL:

content.code_html:
xhttp.open("GET", "demo_get.asp?t=" + Math.random(), true);
xhttp.send();

content.text: If you want to send information with the GET method, add the information to the URL:
content.html: If you want to send information with the GET method, add the information to the URL:

content.code_html:
xhttp.open("GET", "demo_get2.asp?fname=Henry&lname=Ford", true);
xhttp.send();

content.text: POST Requests
A simple POST request:
content.html: A simple POST request:

content.code_html:
xhttp.open("POST", "demo_post.asp", true);
xhttp.send();

content.text: To POST data like an HTML form, add an HTTP header with setRequestHeader(). Specify the data you want to send in the send() method:
content.html: To POST data like an HTML form, add an HTTP header with setRequestHeader(). Specify the data you want to send in the send() method:

content.code_html:
xhttp.open("POST", "demo_post2.asp", true);
xhttp.setRequestHeader("Content-type", "application/x-www-form-urlencoded");
xhttp.send("fname=Henry&lname=Ford");

Method Description
setRequestHeader(header, value) Adds HTTP headers to the request

header: specifies the header name
value: specifies the header value

content.text: The url - A File On a Server
The url parameter of the open() method, is an address to a file on a server:
content.html: The url parameter of the open() method, is an address to a file on a server:

content.code_html: xhttp.open("GET", "ajax_test.asp", true);

content.text: The file can be any kind of file, like .txt and .xml, or server scripting files like .asp and .php (which can perform actions on the server before sending the response back).
content.html: The file can be any kind of file, like .txt and .xml, or server scripting files like .asp and .php (which can perform actions on the server before sending the response back).

content.text: Asynchronous - True or False?
Server requests should be sent asynchronously.
content.html: Server requests should be sent asynchronously.

content.text: The async parameter of the open() method should be set to true:
content.html: The async parameter of the open() method should be set to true:

content.code_html: xhttp.open("GET", "ajax_test.asp", true);

content.text: By sending asynchronously, the JavaScript does not have to wait for the server response, but can instead:
content.html: By sending asynchronously, the JavaScript does not have to wait for the server response, but can instead:

content.text: The onreadystatechange Property
With the XMLHttpRequest object you can define a function to be executed when the request receives an answer.
content.html: With the XMLHttpRequest object you can define a function to be executed when the request receives an answer.

content.text: The function is defined in the onreadystatechange property of the XMLHttpResponse object:
content.html: The function is defined in the onreadystatechange property of the XMLHttpResponse object:

content.code_html:
xhttp.onreadystatechange = function() {
  if (this.readyState == 4 && this.status == 200) {
    document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = this.responseText;
  }
};
xhttp.open("GET", "ajax_info.txt", true);
xhttp.send();

content.text: The "ajax_info.txt" file used in the example above, is a simple text file and looks like this:
content.html: The "ajax_info.txt" file used in the example above, is a simple text file and looks like this:

content.code:
AJAX

AJAX is not a programming language.

AJAX is a technique for accessing web servers from a web page.

AJAX stands for Asynchronous JavaScript And XML.
content.code_html:
<h1>AJAX</h1>
<p>AJAX is not a programming language.</p>
<p>AJAX is a technique for accessing web servers from a web page.</p>
<p>AJAX stands for Asynchronous JavaScript And XML.</p>

content.text: You will learn more about onreadystatechange in a later chapter.
content.html: You will learn more about onreadystatechange in a later chapter.

content.text: Synchronous Request
To execute a synchronous request, change the third parameter in the open() method to false:
content.html: To execute a synchronous request, change the third parameter in the open() method to false:

content.code_html: xhttp.open("GET", "ajax_info.txt", false);

content.text: Sometimes async = false are used for quick testing. You will also find synchronous requests in older JavaScript code.
content.html: Sometimes async = false are used for quick testing. You will also find synchronous requests in older JavaScript code.

content.text: Since the code will wait for server completion, there is no need for an onreadystatechange function:
content.html: Since the code will wait for server completion, there is no need for an onreadystatechange function:

content.code_html:
xhttp.open("GET", "ajax_info.txt", false);
xhttp.send();
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = xhttp.responseText;

content.text: Synchronous XMLHttpRequest (async = false) is not recommended because the JavaScript will stop executing until the server response is ready. If the server is busy or slow, the application will hang or stop.
content.html: Synchronous XMLHttpRequest (async = false) is not recommended because the JavaScript will stop executing until the server response is ready. If the server is busy or slow, the application will hang or stop.

content.text: Synchronous XMLHttpRequest is in the process of being removed from the web standard, but this process can take many years.
content.html: Synchronous XMLHttpRequest is in the process of being removed from the web standard, but this process can take many years.

content.text: Modern developer tools are encouraged to warn about using synchronous requests and may throw an InvalidAccessError exception when it occurs.
content.html: Modern developer tools are encouraged to warn about using synchronous requests and may throw an InvalidAccessError exception when it occurs.
